metadata.title: Analyze YouTube Discourse and Find Troll Bots with Python | by Thomas Hikaru Clark | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Analyze YouTube Discourse and Find Troll Bots with Python
metadata.description: As you might expect in an election year, social media these days is awash in political discourse — some of it reasonable and productive, much of it incendiary. Plenty of articles have been written on…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: generate your own personal API key

all_paragraphs: As you might expect in an election year, social media these days is awash in political discourse — some of it reasonable and productive, much of it incendiary. Plenty of articles have been written on the polarizing “echo chamber” effects of social media, as well as targeted disinformation campaigns and fake news. With the goal of investigating political discourse on YouTube, I will explain how to use the free YouTube Data API to gather YouTube comments into an interesting dataset. We will then use some data science tools such as Pandas and Plotly to visualize this dataset and look for patterns. The quantity of data on YouTube is vast, so I am making the code for this project open-source to encourage others to perform their own analyses as well. Please follow along with the code if you want!

The YouTube Data API allows up to 10,000 requests per day for free to retrieve information on YouTube videos, playlists, comments, and channels. This is all publicly available on YouTube but the API makes retrieving it much easier. The first step is to generate your own personal API key. You will need to use this to replace the placeholders in the accompanying code in order to make API requests.

In my program, you specify a list of channels to scrape, how many videos to scrape from each channel, and how many pages of comments to scrape from each video. (For my analysis, I wanted to get a mix of mainstream political news channels with a variety of ideological slants, such as CNN, MSNBC, and Fox News.) The program then handles the API requests, which return JSON responses containing the requested data. After a little parsing, this data can be appended to a Pandas DataFrame, and when the last API request completes, this DataFrame can be saved to a CSV file. This CSV file can be updated later if we scrape more data, and we can load it back into a DataFrame whenever we want to run an analysis. Here’s a sample of what it looks like after running some collection (note that the only thing we are filtering for here is the channels — we aren’t selecting specifically for political comments):

Currently, I am also exploring more niche political channels to see how these differ from the big networks. I encourage you to try collecting data from various channels — maybe ones you subscribe to, or ones that the YouTube algorithm recommends to you.

Let’s implement a basic keyword search that will pull up comments that contain a given search term. The DataFrame abstraction provided by Pandas makes filtering by channel name, like count, and other features very easy.
Here are two different results for “covid”, which illustrate highly divergent worldviews with regards to the politics of the COVID-19 pandemic:
The Greatest Threat to America #45. Don the Con, blood on his hands for 190,000 Covid-19 deaths and lying about its threat to the American public.

Per the CDC, COVID only killed 9200 people. Everyone else who died WITH COVID had serious medical conditions or died of something completely different and just tested positive. END ALL THE LOCKDOWNS NOW!

Next, we will generate a chronological bar chart of videos showing their like/dislike breakdowns. To do this, we will have to go back to the YouTube Data API to retrieve full data on each unique video in the Comments database (this is because the API response for a CommentsThread request provides the videoID for each comment’s video, but not additional information such as the number of likes and dislikes). The implementation that I settled on was to create a separate videos database with its own corresponding DataFrame and CSV file, and give it a sync function that will ensure it has the information for all videos that appear in the Comments database.
To make bar charts like the one above, I am using Plotly Express, whose bar() function makes creating aesthetically pleasing, interactive charts very easy:

Keyword search is great, but it should leave you feeling like we’ve barely tapped the potential our trove of 100,000 comments. Let’s ratchet up our analysis with word embeddings, specifically word2vec.

As its name suggestions, word2vec converts words to high-dimensional vectors. The main advantage of this is that words that are used in similar ways will be converted to similar vectors (vectors with a high cosine similarity). In this way, different lexical tokens with similar meanings — like “GOP” and “Republicans” — can be mapped to similar locations in 100-dimensional hyperspace (sounds like sci-fi, I know). This method allows us to find much more interesting patterns in our dataset, and fortunately there is a Python implementation available from gensim.

Although visualizing high-dimensional hyperspace is impossible for humans, methods fortunately exist to project these high-dimensional embeddings into two or three dimensions so we can wrap our minds around them. The t-SNE method converts the word2vec vectors into something that we can plot and see, with the crucial constraint that it approximately preserves distance relationships. So vectors that are far away in hyperspace will still be far away after t-SNE, and vectors that are originally close will remain close.

We can use word2vec and t-SNE to plot clusters of vectors that are similar to each other. For a great tutorial on this, check out this post. Given a list of words, we plots the words that are most similar to them according to their word embeddings. Note that similarity is defined based on whether words are used in similar contexts or not, so clusters may not always contain semantic synonyms.

While plotting individual words is insightful, it would be useful to be able to plot entire comments such that similar comments are clustered near each other. Since a comment is a series of words, one thing we could try is to average the word vectors of all the words in a comment, and then plot this resulting vector to represent the entire comment. However, this would give rhetoricexcessive importance to common words like “the” or “and”. To solve this, we can perform a Tf-Idf vectorization and use the inverse document frequencies to weight the words in a comment when we take the average. This gives rare words a higher weight than common words, and there’s an easy-to-use implementation of this in Scikit-Learn. This approach has shortcomings, but it should begin to capture some of the meaning and themes of the YouTube comments.

You may have heard of various attempts by certain state actors to influence the US election with troll armies and automated comment bots. I wanted to see if there is a way to automatically detect likely bot activity purely based on our comments database.

There are a few things that I propose as red flags for bot activity. One is posting a large number of comments in a short span of time. This would either suggest that a person is copying and pasting comments rather than typing them out word for word, or that an automated bot is at work. Another red flag is an account posting the same exact comment on multiple different videos.

Using our database, we can easily filter for the most prolific commenters on a given channel and plot their commenting activity. By plotting comment activity in increments of 10 minutes, I noticed accounts with activity that would be very unusual for a human — like commenting multi-paragraph comments a dozen times in five minutes. Once account posted the same exact comment 60 times in 10 minutes:
“Nationwide civil unrest GOP down 33% Unemployment tripled 190 ,000 Americans dead. Your LIFE is getting WORSE with TRUMP”

Interestingly, the account posted slight variations of the same comment, differing only in a few extra punctuation marks placed at the end of the comment. This makes me suspect that the bot is programmed to evade YouTube’s bot detection measures. In the visualization below, the x-axis is split into 30-minue time increments, and each stacked block represents one comment by the same account. The blocks are color-coded by video.

There are many more examples of this kinds of activity. The bots seem to have various strategies. Some of them just repeatedly post the same comment on a single video. Some post a variety of comments on a variety of videos. As far as I can tell, each bot maintains a consistent pro-Trump or anti-Trump stance, but otherwise seem to follow very similar tactics. I’ve looked up the profiles of several bots, and there isn’t one consistent pattern. Some have very little information associated with them and were created within the last several months. Some have liked videos and playlists, and appear to have once belonged to real people.

Based on our analyses, we have noticed that there is a lot of inflammatory rhetoric on both sides of the political divide. We can use data science and computational linguistics to look for patterns in this discourse. Using this dataset, further analysis could explore some of the following:

On another note, mainstream news outlets like CNN, Fox News, and MSNBC appear to have a serious problem with troll bots. A multitude of accounts post highly inflammatory comments on their videos, occasionally multiple times per minute. Interestingly, there are bots on both sides of the political spectrum — in favor of and opposition to Donald Trump. According to some theories, this could be an attempt to erode confidence in American democracy and the legitimacy of the upcoming election.

I hope the tutorial gave some insight into how to work with APIs in Python, organizing databases with Pandas, visualizing with Plotly, and working with word embeddings in Python. I encourage you to gather your own data and conduct your own investigations using the code as a starting point. There is a lot more work in analyzing political discourse on YouTube, let alone social media as a whole. I’d love to hear your feedback as well as any discoveries you make!
